title: 110_hr5523
content: The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" introduces a license fee on internet gambling operators and requires licensee information reporting. This Act also amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" mandates that licensed internet gambling operators pay a 2 percent fee on all funds deposited into betting accounts each month. The fees collected are deposited into the Treasury's general fund as revenue. The gambling license fees are deposited in the general fund of the Treasury as revenue. The Internet gambling license fee is the exclusive obligation of the operator and cannot be deducted from bet amounts. The term 'Director' is defined as per section 5382 of title 31, US Code. The fee may be treated as an excise tax for administrative purposes. Information Returns.--A new section is added to part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 regarding information concerning persons subject to special provisions. "SEC. 6039J. RETURNS OF INTERNET GAMBLING OPERATORS." Every Internet gambling operator subject to section 4491 must provide required information to the Secretary, including the operator's details and those of individuals placing wagers. Maintaining appropriate records is also necessary as per regulations. The Internet gambling operator must provide the IRS with information on individuals placing wagers, including their name, address, tax information number, gross winnings, wagers, losses, tax withheld, account balances, and deposit/withdrawal amounts. Additionally, the operator must furnish a written statement to each individual with the operator's contact information. The IRS requires Internet gambling operators to provide detailed information on individuals placing wagers, including contact details and financial data. Additionally, operators must furnish a written statement to individuals by January 31 of the following year. The IRS mandates Internet gambling operators to report wagering information and provide statements to individuals. A new section 6039J is added for returns of Internet gambling operators, effective for wagers after December 31, 2008. Additionally, there are provisions for withholding from certain gambling winnings. The IRS requires Internet gambling operators to report wagering information and provide statements to individuals. Amendments are made to section 3402 regarding withholding from certain gambling winnings, including net Internet gambling winnings exceeding $5,000 in a calendar year. The term 'proceeds of net Internet gambling winnings' refers to the amount withdrawn from an account for Internet gambling. 'Net Internet gambling winnings' are gross winnings from Internet wagers minus the amount wagered. The definitions of 'Internet' and 'wager' are based on section 5382 of title 31, United States Code. The amendment made by this section applies to wagers placed with a licensee after December 31, 2008. Net Internet gambling winnings are treated as other reportable payments, with terms defined in section 3402(q)(7) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 4. WITHHOLDING OF TAX ON NONRESIDENT ALIENS. (a) Tax on Nonresident Alien Individuals.--Section 871(a)(1) is amended to include a 30 percent tax on income not connected with United States business, other fixed income, and net Internet gambling income. (b) Exemption for Certain Gambling Winnings.--Section 871(j) is amended to exempt certain gambling winnings, including wagers placed over the Internet. (c) Withholding of Tax on Nonresident Alien Individuals.--Section 1441 is amended to include withholding tax on gains on transfers. The tax law is amended to include a tax on net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year. These changes apply to wagers made after December 31, 2008. The tax law now includes a tax on wagers placed by individuals with unlicensed operators, effective for wagers made after December 31, 2008.
